sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a neutralization reaction
message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change of neutralization for the reaction between hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide, given that the heat of reaction for the neutralization of 1 mole of HCl and 1 mole of NaOH is -57.1 kJ?
message_2:
The standard enthalpy change of neutralization for the reaction between hydrochloric acid (HCl) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) is given as -57.1 kJ/mol. This value represents the amount of heat released when 1 mole of HCl reacts with 1 mole of NaOH to form 1 mole of water and 1 mole of sodium chloride (NaCl) under standard conditions.

The balanced chemical equation for this reaction is:

HCl(aq) + NaOH(aq) â†’ H2O(l) + NaCl(aq)

Since the heat of reaction is given for the neutralization of 1 mole of HCl and 1 mole of NaOH, the standard enthalpy change of neutralization for this reaction is -57.1 kJ/mol.
